message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The information in the question suggests that the cytotoxic T cells are inducing apoptosis, which is most likely due to the secretion of Granzyme B. Bcl-2 is an anti-apoptotic protein, TNF-α can induce apoptosis but is not typically secreted by T cells, and caspases are enzymes involved in the apoptotic pathway but are not secreted.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cytotoxic T cells are known to secrete granzyme B, which can trigger apoptosis in target cells. Bcl-2 is an anti-apoptotic protein. TNF-α can induce apoptosis in some cells but it is not typically secreted by cytotoxic T cells. Caspases are proteases that play a role in the process of apoptosis but they are typically activated by intracellular signals rather than external factors such as secretion by other cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Granzyme B is a granule exocytose of cytotoxic T cells that can induce apoptosis in target cells. Bcl-2 is an anti-apoptotic protein, TNF-alpha can induce apoptosis through multiple pathways, and caspases are enzymes involved in apoptosis but are not secreted by cytotoxic T cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Granzyme B is a protein secreted by cytotoxic T cells that can initiate the apoptotic pathway by cleaving various substrates within the target cell. Bcl-2 is an anti-apoptotic protein and would not cause apoptosis. TNF-α can induce apoptosis, but it is not the most likely cause in this case. Caspases are enzymes involved in the apoptotic pathway but are activated downstream of the initial trigger, such as Granzyme B.

We refer to the article "Apoptosis" on the National Center for Biotechnology Information website for help. Cytotoxic T cells release granzyme B, which is a protease that can initiate apoptosis by cleaving and activating caspases. Bcl-2 is an anti-apoptotic protein, TNF-α can induce apoptosis but is not the most likely cause in this case, and caspases are activated by granzyme B but not secreted by T cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cytotoxic T cells use granzyme B to induce apoptosis in targeted cells. Bcl-2 is an anti-apoptotic protein, TNF-α induces apoptosis in macrophages, and caspases are enzymes involved in the apoptotic process.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cytotoxic T cells release perforin and granzyme B to cause apoptosis in target cells. Among the options, only Granzyme B is secreted by cytotoxic T cells. Bcl-2 protein and Caspases are involved in regulating apoptosis, while TNF-α is mainly involved in inflammation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cytotoxic T cells induce apoptosis in target cells by releasing the protein granzyme B. Bcl-2 is anti-apoptotic, TNF-α induces apoptosis in some cases but not in this specific scenario, and caspases are enzymes involved in the actual process of apoptosis but they are not secreted by cytotoxic T cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Granzyme B is an enzyme secreted by cytotoxic T cells that induces apoptosis in the target cell. Bcl-2 is an anti-apoptotic protein, TNF-α is a pro-inflammatory cytokine, and caspases are enzymes involved in the apoptosis pathway, but they are not secreted by cytotoxic T cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cytotoxic T cells secrete perforin and granzyme B to induce apoptosis in target cells. Bcl-2 is an anti-apoptotic protein, TNF-α can induce apoptosis but only when present at high levels, and caspases are enzymes that play a role in the apoptotic pathway but are not secreted by cytotoxic T cells.
